elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Two new one dimensional copper(II) polymers based on tetranuclear units was achieved via self-assembly from N3O2 pentadentate ligand and structurally characterized.

Abstract

One-dimensional copper(II) polymers [(Cu4L2)(NO3)4] n  (1) and [(Cu4L2)Cl4] n  (2) (H2L=salicylaldehyde-2-pyridinecarboxyl-hydrazone) were achieved via self-assembly. The Cu⋯Cu separations were ca. 2.90 and 4.75Å for the phenoxide oxygen bridged pair and the N-N bridged pair with antiferromagnetic spin exchanges between Cu(II) ions.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Within the field of supramolecular inorganic chemistry, self-assembly provides direct access to complex architectures comprising spatially and geometrically well-defined arrays of metal ions . The application of metal–ligand interactions has proved particularly fruitful, and a considerable variety of frequently predesigned molecular architectures  with unusual and interesting properties  have been assembled. Schiff-base ligands are excellent ligands and employed for their ease of synthesis and high yield in a single-step reaction from commercial and inexpensive reagents. It allows us to systematically probe the effect of modifications to the ligand backbone through which we are attempting to control the precise topography, or microarchitecture, of the arrays . Among them, diazone Schiff-base ligands, with two coordination compartments linked by a single N–N bridge, have received intense attention due to their structural and functional diversities . These ligands usually lead to a situation where a variety of different structural types, such as chains, metallomacrocycles, and metallocrowns, are observed on the basis of the free rotation of the metal coordination planes around the N–N single bond .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Within the field of supramolecular inorganic chemistry, self-assembly provides direct access to complex architectures comprising spatially and geometrically well-defined arrays of metal ions . The application of metal-ligand interactions has proved particularly fruitful, and a considerable variety of frequently predesigned molecular architectures  with unusual and interesting properties  have been assembled. Schiff-base ligands are excellent ligands and employed for their ease of synthesis and high yield in a single-step reaction from commercial and inexpensive reagents. It allows us to systematically probe the effect of modifications to the ligand backbone through which we are attempting to control the precise topography, or microarchitecture, of the arrays . Among them, diazone Schiff-base ligands, with two coordination compartments linked by a single N-N bridge, have received intense attention due to their structural and functional diversities . These ligands usually lead to a situation where a variety of different structural types, such as chains, metallomacrocycles, and metallocrowns, are observed on the basis of the free rotation of the metal coordination planes around the N-N single bond .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">On the other hand, the superexchange interaction between paramagnetic ions is tunable through the control of the aromatic nature of bridging ligands and their coordination modes . The use of the diazine or diazone as a bridge has been an intriguing synthetic approach to produce copper compounds due to their remarkable diversities in structural and magnetic behaviors, i.e., the magnetic exchange situations depend cleanly on the angle of rotation of the copper magnetic orbital around the N–N bond . As a part of our continuing investigations on this type of Schiff-based ligands and their transition metal compounds , here we report the construction of polynuclear copper complexes from the Schiff-base ligand, salicylaldehyde 2-pyridinecarboxylhydrazone H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>

The use of the diazine or diazone as a bridge has been an intriguing synthetic approach to produce copper compounds due to their remarkable diversities in structural and magnetic behaviors, i.e., the magnetic exchange situations depend cleanly on the angle of rotation of the copper magnetic orbital around the N-N bond . As a part of our continuing investigations on this type of Schiff-based ligands and their transition metal compounds , here we report the construction of polynuclear copper complexes from the Schiff-base ligand, salicylaldehyde 2-pyridinecarboxylhydrazone H2L ( ).

The molecule lied in the conversion center with the Cu⋯Cu separations of 2.93 and 4.76<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for the phenoxide oxygen bridged pair, Cu(1)⋯Cu(1A), and the N–N bridged pair, Cu(1)⋯Cu(2) (symmetry code (A) −<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, −<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>), respectively. The Cu(1)–N(1)–N(2)–Cu(2) torsion angle was ca. 175°. The Cu(1) atom was bound to a NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> tridentate donors of the ligand and a phenyl oxygen atom from another ligand. The Cu(2) atom was coordinated to the N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> didentate donors of the ligand and the four oxygen atoms from two nitrate groups. The Cu–O (phenol) distances were 1.926(3) and 1.954(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, Cu–O (carbonzone) distances was 1.942(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the Cu–N distances were in the range of 1.927(3)–1.973(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. The C–N and N–N bond distances in L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> were intermediate between formal single and double bonds, pointing to the extensive delocalization over the entire molecular skeleton.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Reaction of the ligand H2L  with Cu(NO3)2 ⋅6H2O gave the one-dimensional coordinated polymer 1, [Cu4L2(NO3)4] n , in high yield via self-assembly . Crystal structure analysis revealed that the compound 1 consisted of a tetranuclear planar neutral molecular unit ( ) . The molecule lied in the conversion center with the Cu⋯Cu separations of 2.93 and 4.76Å for the phenoxide oxygen bridged pair, Cu(1)⋯Cu(1A), and the N-N bridged pair, Cu(1)⋯Cu(2) (symmetry code (A) -x, 1- y, -z), respectively. The Cu(1)-N(1)-N(2)-Cu(2) torsion angle was ca. 175°. The Cu(1) atom was bound to a NO2 tridentate donors of the ligand and a phenyl oxygen atom from another ligand. The Cu(2) atom was coordinated to the N2 didentate donors of the ligand and the four oxygen atoms from two nitrate groups. The Cu-O (phenol) distances were 1.926(3) and 1.954(3)Å, Cu-O (carbonzone) distances was 1.942(3)Å, and the Cu-N distances were in the range of 1.927(3)-1.973(3)Å, respectively. The C-N and N-N bond distances in L2- were intermediate between formal single and double bonds, pointing to the extensive delocalization over the entire molecular skeleton.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Reaction of the ligand H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L with CuCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O gave the compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> containing the chloro-bridging Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> units in a high yield via self-assembly (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>) . One chloride anion bridged two copper centers Cu(1) and Cu(4A), the other chloride anion bridged two copper centers Cu(4) and Cu(4B) to form the one-dimensional chain with the Cu(2) positioned outside (symmetry code (A) −<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>; (B) −1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>). The separations of the single N–N bond bridged Cu(1)⋯Cu(2) and Cu(3)⋯Cu(4) were 4.75 and 4.77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. The separation of the phenoxide oxygen bridged Cu(1)⋯Cu(3) was 2.85<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. These separations were similar to those in the compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. The Cu(1) and Cu(3) atoms were coordinated in a square pyramidal geometry with a NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> tridentate donor and the bridging phenoxide oxygen comprising the basal plane and a bridging chloride atom from neighbor unit occupied the apical site. The Cu(1)–O(3)–Cu(3) angle of 94° was quite smaller than that of the compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and most related phenoxide oxygen bridged dinuclear and tetranuclear copper compounds . The Cu(2) atom was coordinated by the didentate donors of the ligand and the two chloride ions, respectively, forming a tetrahedron structure. The torsion angles were 178.4 and 172.6° for Cu(1)–N(1)–N(2)–Cu(2) and Cu(3)–N(4)–N(5)–Cu(4), respectively. The Cu(4) atom was coordinated to a didentate donors of the ligand, two chloride ions and a bridging chloride, respectively, forming a trigonal bipyramidal structure. The Cu–O (phenol) distances were 1.930(4) and 1.943(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, Cu–O (carbonzone) distances were in the range of 1.937(4)–1.958(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the Cu–N distances were in the range of 1.916(6)–2.026(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. It was interesting that the aromatic ring containing carbon atom C(14) was almost parallel to the related pyridine ring containing nitrogen atom N(6A) of an adjacent tetranuclear unit in the 1D chain (dihedral angle between the two planes was ca. 8.5°) with a close intermolecular separation of ca. 3.57<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for the stacked pair. The stacking interactions were also found between the adjacent planar molecular skeletons to stabilize the 1D chain. Furthermore, such chains were interconnected through the π–π stacking interactions forming a two-dimensional network. The dihedral angle of the stacking pair was 17.7° with the center-to-center separation of ca. 3.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and the shortest interplanar atom⋯atom separation of ca. 3.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Reaction of the ligand H2L with CuCl2 ⋅2H2O gave the compound 2 containing the chloro-bridging Cu4L2Cl4 units in a high yield via self-assembly ( ) . One chloride anion bridged two copper centers Cu(1) and Cu(4A), the other chloride anion bridged two copper centers Cu(4) and Cu(4B) to form the one-dimensional chain with the Cu(2) positioned outside (symmetry code (A) -x, 2- y, 2- z; (B) -1- x, 2- y, 2- z). The separations of the single N-N bond bridged Cu(1)⋯Cu(2) and Cu(3)⋯Cu(4) were 4.75 and 4.77Å, respectively. The separation of the phenoxide oxygen bridged Cu(1)⋯Cu(3) was 2.85Å. These separations were similar to those in the compound 1. The Cu(1) and Cu(3) atoms were coordinated in a square pyramidal geometry with a NO2 tridentate donor and the bridging phenoxide oxygen comprising the basal plane and a bridging chloride atom from neighbor unit occupied the apical site. The Cu(1)-O(3)-Cu(3) angle of 94° was quite smaller than that of the compound 2 and most related phenoxide oxygen bridged dinuclear and tetranuclear copper compounds . The Cu(2) atom was coordinated by the didentate donors of the ligand and the two chloride ions, respectively, forming a tetrahedron structure. The torsion angles were 178.4 and 172.6° for Cu(1)-N(1)-N(2)-Cu(2) and Cu(3)-N(4)-N(5)-Cu(4), respectively. The Cu(4) atom was coordinated to a didentate donors of the ligand, two chloride ions and a bridging chloride, respectively, forming a trigonal bipyramidal structure. The Cu-O (phenol) distances were 1.930(4) and 1.943(5)Å, Cu-O (carbonzone) distances were in the range of 1.937(4)-1.958(5)Å, and the Cu-N distances were in the range of 1.916(6)-2.026(6)Å, respectively. It was interesting that the aromatic ring containing carbon atom C(14) was almost parallel to the related pyridine ring containing nitrogen atom N(6A) of an adjacent tetranuclear unit in the 1D chain (dihedral angle between the two planes was ca. 8.5°) with a close intermolecular separation of ca. 3.57Å for the stacked pair. The stacking interactions were also found between the adjacent planar molecular skeletons to stabilize the 1D chain. Furthermore, such chains were interconnected through the π-π stacking interactions forming a two-dimensional network. The dihedral angle of the stacking pair was 17.7° with the center-to-center separation of ca. 3.7Å and the shortest interplanar atom⋯atom separation of ca. 3.3Å, respectively.

elements.clean_text: The magnetic properties of the compounds 1 and 2 have been investigated at a field of 2KOe in the temperature range 1.8-300K. The overall magnetic behaviors of the compounds 1 and 2 correspond to paramagnetic systems with antiferromagnetic coupling interactions. For the compound 1, the χ m T value of 1.09emumol-1 K at 300K is significantly less than that of a spin-only value per formula unit ( ). With decreasing temperature, the χ m T value first decreases gradually till reaching 0.65emumol-1 K at 50K, and then decreases rapidly below this temperature till reaching zero at 5K. For the compound 2, the χ m T value at 300K is 1.13emumol-1 K and decreases gradually with decreasing temperature at the range of 300-30K. Below 30K, the χ m T value is closed to zero.

elements.clean_text: In summary, this paper describes two new one-dimensional copper(II) polymers using N3O2 pentadentate ligand via self-assembly. The tetranuclear units of the complex 1 and 2 were bridged by the     NO   3   -     and Cl- anions into a chain through the weak coordination bonds, respectively. Magnetic properties of the two complexes exhibited an antiferromagnetic spin exchange interaction between Cu(II) ions.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Reaction of the ligand H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L  with Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O gave the one-dimensional coordinated polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>, in high yield via self-assembly . Crystal structure analysis revealed that the compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> consisted of a tetranuclear planar neutral molecular unit (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>) . The molecule lied in the conversion center with the Cu⋯Cu separations of 2.93 and 4.76<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for the phenoxide oxygen bridged pair, Cu(1)⋯Cu(1A), and the N–N bridged pair, Cu(1)⋯Cu(2) (symmetry code (A) −<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, −<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>), respectively. The Cu(1)–N(1)–N(2)–Cu(2) torsion angle was ca. 175°. The Cu(1) atom was bound to a NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> tridentate donors of the ligand and a phenyl oxygen atom from another ligand. The Cu(2) atom was coordinated to the N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> didentate donors of the ligand and the four oxygen atoms from two nitrate groups. The Cu–O (phenol) distances were 1.926(3) and 1.954(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, Cu–O (carbonzone) distances was 1.942(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the Cu–N distances were in the range of 1.927(3)–1.973(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. The C–N and N–N bond distances in L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> were intermediate between formal single and double bonds, pointing to the extensive delocalization over the entire molecular skeleton.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">Detailed structural analyses revealed that the weak coordination bonds of the <mml:math altimg="si1.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mrow>
<mml:msubsup>
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mi mathvariant="normal">NO</mml:mi>
</mml:mrow>
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mn>3</mml:mn>
</mml:mrow>
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mo>-</mml:mo>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:msubsup>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:math> linked the planar tetranuclear molecules together featuring a one-dimensional chain. As shown in , the Cu(1) was coordinated in a 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2 lengthened octahedral geometry with two weak Cu–O bonds in the axial positions. These 1D chains were interconnected through the π–π stacking interactions between the molecular skeletons forming a two-dimensional network. The dihedral angle of the stacking pair was 3.3° with the center-to-center separation of ca. 3.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å between the two aromatic rings and the shortest interplanar atom⋯atom separation of 3.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">Reaction of the ligand H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L with CuCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O gave the compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> containing the chloro-bridging Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> units in a high yield via self-assembly (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>) . One chloride anion bridged two copper centers Cu(1) and Cu(4A), the other chloride anion bridged two copper centers Cu(4) and Cu(4B) to form the one-dimensional chain with the Cu(2) positioned outside (symmetry code (A) −<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>; (B) −1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>). The separations of the single N–N bond bridged Cu(1)⋯Cu(2) and Cu(3)⋯Cu(4) were 4.75 and 4.77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. The separation of the phenoxide oxygen bridged Cu(1)⋯Cu(3) was 2.85<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. These separations were similar to those in the compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. The Cu(1) and Cu(3) atoms were coordinated in a square pyramidal geometry with a NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> tridentate donor and the bridging phenoxide oxygen comprising the basal plane and a bridging chloride atom from neighbor unit occupied the apical site. The Cu(1)–O(3)–Cu(3) angle of 94° was quite smaller than that of the compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and most related phenoxide oxygen bridged dinuclear and tetranuclear copper compounds . The Cu(2) atom was coordinated by the didentate donors of the ligand and the two chloride ions, respectively, forming a tetrahedron structure. The torsion angles were 178.4 and 172.6° for Cu(1)–N(1)–N(2)–Cu(2) and Cu(3)–N(4)–N(5)–Cu(4), respectively. The Cu(4) atom was coordinated to a didentate donors of the ligand, two chloride ions and a bridging chloride, respectively, forming a trigonal bipyramidal structure. The Cu–O (phenol) distances were 1.930(4) and 1.943(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, Cu–O (carbonzone) distances were in the range of 1.937(4)–1.958(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the Cu–N distances were in the range of 1.916(6)–2.026(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. It was interesting that the aromatic ring containing carbon atom C(14) was almost parallel to the related pyridine ring containing nitrogen atom N(6A) of an adjacent tetranuclear unit in the 1D chain (dihedral angle between the two planes was ca. 8.5°) with a close intermolecular separation of ca. 3.57<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for the stacked pair. The stacking interactions were also found between the adjacent planar molecular skeletons to stabilize the 1D chain. Furthermore, such chains were interconnected through the π–π stacking interactions forming a two-dimensional network. cln_elements.clean_text:
Reaction of the ligand H2L  with Cu(NO3)2 ⋅6H2O gave the one-dimensional coordinated polymer 1, [Cu4L2(NO3)4] n , in high yield via self-assembly . Crystal structure analysis revealed that the compound 1 consisted of a tetranuclear planar neutral molecular unit ( ) . The molecule lied in the conversion center with the Cu⋯Cu separations of 2.93 and 4.76Å for the phenoxide oxygen bridged pair, Cu(1)⋯Cu(1A), and the N-N bridged pair, Cu(1)⋯Cu(2) (symmetry code (A) -x, 1- y, -z), respectively. The Cu(1)-N(1)-N(2)-Cu(2) torsion angle was ca. 175°. The Cu(1) atom was bound to a NO2 tridentate donors of the ligand and a phenyl oxygen atom from another ligand. The Cu(2) atom was coordinated to the N2 didentate donors of the ligand and the four oxygen atoms from two nitrate groups. The Cu-O (phenol) distances were 1.926(3) and 1.954(3)Å, Cu-O (carbonzone) distances was 1.942(3)Å, and the Cu-N distances were in the range of 1.927(3)-1.973(3)Å, respectively. The C-N and N-N bond distances in L2- were intermediate between formal single and double bonds, pointing to the extensive delocalization over the entire molecular skeleton.

Detailed structural analyses revealed that the weak coordination bonds of the     NO   3   -     linked the planar tetranuclear molecules together featuring a one-dimensional chain. As shown in , the Cu(1) was coordinated in a 4+2 lengthened octahedral geometry with two weak Cu-O bonds in the axial positions. These 1D chains were interconnected through the π-π stacking interactions between the molecular skeletons forming a two-dimensional network. The dihedral angle of the stacking pair was 3.3° with the center-to-center separation of ca. 3.8Å between the two aromatic rings and the shortest interplanar atom⋯atom separation of 3.5Å, respectively.

Reaction of the ligand H2L with CuCl2 ⋅2H2O gave the compound 2 containing the chloro-bridging Cu4L2Cl4 units in a high yield via self-assembly ( ) . One chloride anion bridged two copper centers Cu(1) and Cu(4A), the other chloride anion bridged two copper centers Cu(4) and Cu(4B) to form the one-dimensional chain with the Cu(2) positioned outside (symmetry code (A) -x, 2- y, 2- z; (B) -1- x, 2- y, 2- z). The separations of the single N-N bond bridged Cu(1)⋯Cu(2) and Cu(3)⋯Cu(4) were 4.75 and 4.77Å, respectively. The separation of the phenoxide oxygen bridged Cu(1)⋯Cu(3) was 2.85Å. These separations were similar to those in the compound 1. The Cu(1) and Cu(3) atoms were coordinated in a square pyramidal geometry with a NO2 tridentate donor and the bridging phenoxide oxygen comprising the basal plane and a bridging chloride atom from neighbor unit occupied the apical site. The Cu(1)-O(3)-Cu(3) angle of 94° was quite smaller than that of the compound 2 and most related phenoxide oxygen bridged dinuclear and tetranuclear copper compounds . The Cu(2) atom was coordinated by the didentate donors of the ligand and the two chloride ions, respectively, forming a tetrahedron structure. The torsion angles were 178.4 and 172.6° for Cu(1)-N(1)-N(2)-Cu(2) and Cu(3)-N(4)-N(5)-Cu(4), respectively. The Cu(4) atom was coordinated to a didentate donors of the ligand, two chloride ions and a bridging chloride, respectively, forming a trigonal bipyramidal structure. The Cu-O (phenol) distances were 1.930(4) and 1.943(5)Å, Cu-O (carbonzone) distances were in the range of 1.937(4)-1.958(5)Å, and the Cu-N distances were in the range of 1.916(6)-2.026(6)Å, respectively. It was interesting that the aromatic ring containing carbon atom C(14) was almost parallel to the related pyridine ring containing nitrogen atom N(6A) of an adjacent tetranuclear unit in the 1D chain (dihedral angle between the two planes was ca. 8.5°) with a close intermolecular separation of ca. 3.57Å for the stacked pair. The stacking interactions were also found between the adjacent planar molecular skeletons to stabilize the 1D chain. Furthermore, such chains were interconnected through the π-π stacking interactions forming a two-dimensional network. The dihedral angle of the stacking pair was 17.7° with the center-to-center separation of ca. 3.7Å and the shortest interplanar atom⋯atom separation of ca. 3.3Å, respectively.

The magnetic properties of the compounds 1 and 2 have been investigated at a field of 2KOe in the temperature range 1.8-300K. The overall magnetic behaviors of the compounds 1 and 2 correspond to paramagnetic systems with antiferromagnetic coupling interactions. For the compound 1, the χ m T value of 1.09emumol-1 K at 300K is significantly less than that of a spin-only value per formula unit ( ). With decreasing temperature, the χ m T value first decreases gradually till reaching 0.65emumol-1 K at 50K, and then decreases rapidly below this temperature till reaching zero at 5K. For the compound 2, the χ m T value at 300K is 1.13emumol-1 K and decreases gradually with decreasing temperature at the range of 300-30K. Below 30K, the χ m T value is closed to zero.
